X-ray analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a three-dimensional (3D) threefold interpenetrated diamodiod architecture, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a 3D fourfold interpenetrated polyrotaxane, while complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a 2D network with paddle wheel dimeric cadmium–tetracarboxylate building units.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The coordination polymers, [Ni(3,5-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (1), [Co(3,5-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (2) and [Cd(3,5-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (3), have been synthesized by the hydrothermal method. X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 has a three-dimensional (3D) threefold interpenetrated diamodiod architecture, complex 2 is a 3D fourfold interpenetrated polyrotaxane, while complex 3 is a 2D network with paddle wheel dimeric cadmium-tetracarboxylate building units.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Three coordination polymers, namely [Ni(3,4-pmb)(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Co(3,5-pmb)(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [Cd(3,5-pmb)(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) (3,4-pmb<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3,4-bis[4-pyridylmethyleneoxyl]benzoate, 3,5-pmb<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3,5-bis[4-pyridylmethyleneoxyl]benzoate and bdc<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,4-benzenedicarboxylate), have been synthesized by the hydrothermal method and structurally characterized. The X-ray structural analysis reveals that the three complexes possess different structural motifs. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a three-dimensional (3D) threefold interpenetrated diamondiod architecture and crystallizes in the monoclinic <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group, in which each Ni(II) atom is connected to four other Ni(II) centers, resulting in the formation of a (4,4) diamondoid network. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a (3D) fourfold interpenetrated polyrotaxane and crystallizes in the monoclinic <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2(1)/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group. It is constructed by four equivalent independent 3D units and entangled by each other give a 3D fourfold structure. Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a 2D network in which two Cd(II) centers are bridged equivalently by four carboxylate groups of different pmb and bdc ligands, forming a paddle wheel secondary building unit (SBU) (CdO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N), and the five coordinating atoms in the CdO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N unit occupy the vertices of square-pyramidal structure. Moreover, complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibits strong photoluminescence at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three coordination polymers, namely [Ni(3,4-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (1), [Co(3,5-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (2) and [Cd(3,5-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (3) (3,4-pmb=3,4-bis[4-pyridylmethyleneoxyl]benzoate, 3,5-pmb=3,5-bis[4-pyridylmethyleneoxyl]benzoate and bdc=1,4-benzenedicarboxylate), have been synthesized by the hydrothermal method and structurally characterized. The X-ray structural analysis reveals that the three complexes possess different structural motifs. Complex 1 has a three-dimensional (3D) threefold interpenetrated diamondiod architecture and crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group, in which each Ni(II) atom is connected to four other Ni(II) centers, resulting in the formation of a (4,4) diamondoid network. Complex 2 is a (3D) fourfold interpenetrated polyrotaxane and crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/c space group. It is constructed by four equivalent independent 3D units and entangled by each other give a 3D fourfold structure. Complex 3 is a 2D network in which two Cd(II) centers are bridged equivalently by four carboxylate groups of different pmb and bdc ligands, forming a paddle wheel secondary building unit (SBU) (CdO4N), and the five coordinating atoms in the CdO4N unit occupy the vertices of square-pyramidal structure. Moreover, complex 3 exhibits strong photoluminescence at room temperature.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The rational design and construction of coordination polymers based upon assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands have attracted much attention not only because of their potential application as functional materials in host guest chemistry, ion exchange and catalysis, and for the development of optical, magnetic and electronic devices, but also for their intriguing structural topologies . Among the various architectures, interpenetrating and intervening phenomena are frequently observed, especially in adamantanoid networks and polyrotaxane structures . Compared to rigid bridging ligands, flexible bridging tectons can produce some unique frameworks with beautiful aesthetics and useful properties because of their flexibility and conformational freedom . Recently, a series of systematic studies on this subject have demonstrated that an interpenetrated array cannot prevent porosity but can enhance the porous functionalities of supramolecular frameworks , and also they have been considered as potential super-hard materials , and posses peculiar magnetic and electrical properties . In addition, entangled systems are common in biology (as seen in catenanes, rotaxanes and molecular knots) and have attracted a great deal of attention from chemists because of their interesting properties and potential applications ranging from drug delivery vehicles to sensor devices . On the other hand, benzenedicarboxylic acid has been extensively employed to construct carboxylate bridged coordination polymers exhibiting high porosity and topological diversity with different dimensions . On the basis of the aforementioned points, we have used the flexible ligands 3,4-pmb and 3,5-pmb as organic linkers, and the second bridging ligand benzenedicarboxylate as a coligand, to synthesize a series of new metal-organic frameworks. Herein, we describe the preparation and crystal structures of two interpenetrated networks and one intervened network, namely, [Ni(3,4-pmb)(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Co(3,5-pmb)(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [Cd(3,5-pmb)(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) (3,4-pmb<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3,4-bis[4-pyridylmethyleneoxyl]benzoate, 3,5-pmb<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3,5-bis[4-pyridylmethyleneoxyl]benzoate, and bdc<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 3D threefold diamondoid framework, and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a 3D fourfold polyrotaxane, while <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a 2D intervened framework without any interlocking. The luminescence property of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was also investigated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design and construction of coordination polymers based upon assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands have attracted much attention not only because of their potential application as functional materials in host guest chemistry, ion exchange and catalysis, and for the development of optical, magnetic and electronic devices, but also for their intriguing structural topologies . Among the various architectures, interpenetrating and intervening phenomena are frequently observed, especially in adamantanoid networks and polyrotaxane structures . Compared to rigid bridging ligands, flexible bridging tectons can produce some unique frameworks with beautiful aesthetics and useful properties because of their flexibility and conformational freedom . Recently, a series of systematic studies on this subject have demonstrated that an interpenetrated array cannot prevent porosity but can enhance the porous functionalities of supramolecular frameworks , and also they have been considered as potential super-hard materials , and posses peculiar magnetic and electrical properties . In addition, entangled systems are common in biology (as seen in catenanes, rotaxanes and molecular knots) and have attracted a great deal of attention from chemists because of their interesting properties and potential applications ranging from drug delivery vehicles to sensor devices . On the other hand, benzenedicarboxylic acid has been extensively employed to construct carboxylate bridged coordination polymers exhibiting high porosity and topological diversity with different dimensions . On the basis of the aforementioned points, we have used the flexible ligands 3,4-pmb and 3,5-pmb as organic linkers, and the second bridging ligand benzenedicarboxylate as a coligand, to synthesize a series of new metal-organic frameworks. Herein, we describe the preparation and crystal structures of two interpenetrated networks and one intervened network, namely, [Ni(3,4-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (1), [Co(3,5-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (2) and [Cd(3,5-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (3) (3,4-pmb=3,4-bis[4-pyridylmethyleneoxyl]benzoate, 3,5-pmb=3,5-bis[4-pyridylmethyleneoxyl]benzoate, and bdc=1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) ( ). Compound 1 is a 3D threefold diamondoid framework, and 2 is a 3D fourfold polyrotaxane, while 3 is a 2D intervened framework without any interlocking. The luminescence property of complex 3 was also investigated.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and analyses

All chemicals were commercially purchased and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400CHN Elemental Analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range 400-4000cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer as KBr pellets. The emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Syntheses of the ligands and the complexes</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis of 3,5-pmb and 3,4-pmb</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">3,5-Dihydroxybenzoic acid (15.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), ethanol (53<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) and sulfuric acid (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) were mixed and refluxed for 6–7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The excess ethanol was removed under vacuum, and then the reaction mixture was extracted with ethylacetate. The extracted solution was washed once with water, and then with NaHCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> aqueous solution<ce:inf loc="post">.</ce:inf> After drying with Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, the solvent was evaporated. To 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol (3.64<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) of the product, 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol (6.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) of 4-pycolyl chloride hydrochloride and 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol (4.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) of NaOH and 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml DMF were added. The mixture was heated at 70<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, and then the product was washed with ethanol and filtered. The solid product was transferred to a 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml round bottom flask, 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml of 5% NaOH solution was added and the resulting solution was refluxed at 70<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, then the mixture was transferred into a 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml beaker. After adding 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml of distilled and concentrated HCl drop by drop, a light brown precipitate was obtained at about pH 6, which was washed with ethanol and filtered. Yield: 72%. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (336.11): C, 67.85; H, 4.79; N, 8.33%. Found: C, 67.91; H, 4.98; N, 8.26%. M.p. for the crude product is 128<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of the ligands and the complexes

Synthesis of 3,5-pmb and 3,4-pmb

3,5-Dihydroxybenzoic acid (15.4g), ethanol (53ml) and sulfuric acid (4ml) were mixed and refluxed for 6-7h. The excess ethanol was removed under vacuum, and then the reaction mixture was extracted with ethylacetate. The extracted solution was washed once with water, and then with NaHCO3 aqueous solution. After drying with Na2SO4, the solvent was evaporated. To 20mmol (3.64g) of the product, 40mmol (6.5g) of 4-pycolyl chloride hydrochloride and 120mmol (4.8g) of NaOH and 10ml DMF were added. The mixture was heated at 70°C for 10h, and then the product was washed with ethanol and filtered. The solid product was transferred to a 100ml round bottom flask, 50ml of 5% NaOH solution was added and the resulting solution was refluxed at 70°C for 5h, then the mixture was transferred into a 400ml beaker. After adding 50ml of distilled and concentrated HCl drop by drop, a light brown precipitate was obtained at about pH 6, which was washed with ethanol and filtered. Yield: 72%. Anal. Calc. for C19H16N2O4 (336.11): C, 67.85; H, 4.79; N, 8.33%. Found: C, 67.91; H, 4.98; N, 8.26%. M.p. for the crude product is 128°C.

Yield: 60%. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (336.11): C, 67.85; H, 4.79; N, 8.33. Found: C, 67.91; H, 4.98; N, 8.26%.</ce:para>

[Ni(3,4-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (1)

Compound 1 was prepared from a mixture of NiCl2 ⋅6H2O (0.3mmol, 0.066g), 3,4-pmb (0.2mmol, 0.073g), bdc (0.2mmol, 0.033g) and NaOH (0.6mmol, 0.024g) in 8ml distilled water. This mixture was heated in a sealed Teflon lined steel autoclave at 150°C for three days. After the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10°C/h, green crystals of 1 were obtained (yield: 58% based on Ni). Anal. Calc. for C23H15N2O10Ni (538.08): C, 51.34; H, 2.81; N, 5.21. Found: C, 50.69; H, 2.79; N, 5.20%.

<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallography analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A suitable single crystal of each complex was mounted on a glass fiber and used for X-ray diffraction analyses. Data were collected at 293(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K on a Bruker ApexII CCD diffractmeter using the scan technique with Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71069<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Absorption corrections were applied using the multi-scan technique . The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-square techniques on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using <ce:small-caps>shlxl</ce:small-caps>-97 . Further details of the X-ray structural analysis for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and angles for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography analysis

A suitable single crystal of each complex was mounted on a glass fiber and used for X-ray diffraction analyses. Data were collected at 293(2)K on a Bruker ApexII CCD diffractmeter using the scan technique with Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71069Å). Absorption corrections were applied using the multi-scan technique . The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-square techniques on F 2 using shlxl-97 . Further details of the X-ray structural analysis for compounds 1-3 are given in  . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1-3 are listed in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Description of the structures</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The hydrothermal reactions of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc and the corresponding metal salt with the pyridyl-containing ligands at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C have afforded crystals of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc is completely deprotonated to coordinate to the metal center. In each complex, the carboxylate groups of bdc and the carboxylate group of the pmb ligands adopt similar coordination modes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Description of the structures

The hydrothermal reactions of H2bdc and the corresponding metal salt with the pyridyl-containing ligands at 150°C have afforded crystals of complexes 1-3. H2bdc is completely deprotonated to coordinate to the metal center. In each complex, the carboxylate groups of bdc and the carboxylate group of the pmb ligands adopt similar coordination modes.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>[Ni(3,4-pmb)(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a 3D threefold interpenetrated adamantanoid structure. As is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, each Ni(II) center adopts a distorted octahedral geometry, supplied by two nitrogen atoms from different 3,4-pmb ligands (the average Ni–N distance is 2.037<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the N–Ni–N angle is 94.82°), and four oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of bdc and pmb in a chelating mode. The Ni–O bond distances are in the range 2.07–2.14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the O–Ni–O bond angles range from 62.3° to 98.1°. If each chelating carboxylate groups is treated as one connecting point, the nickel center has a pseudotetrahedral geometry . Each Ni(II) atom is thus connected to four other Ni(II) centers, resulting in the formation of a diamondoid network. The Ni···Ni separations observed were in the range 10.65–13.13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The long spacers between the coordination sites result in large cavities with adamantanoid cages (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). In order to minimize the big void cavities and to stabilize the framework naturally, the potential voids are effectively filled by mutual interpenetration of other two independent equivalent frameworks, generating a threefold network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
[Ni(3,4-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (1)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 has a 3D threefold interpenetrated adamantanoid structure. As is shown in  , each Ni(II) center adopts a distorted octahedral geometry, supplied by two nitrogen atoms from different 3,4-pmb ligands (the average Ni-N distance is 2.037Å and the N-Ni-N angle is 94.82°), and four oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of bdc and pmb in a chelating mode. The Ni-O bond distances are in the range 2.07-2.14Å, and the O-Ni-O bond angles range from 62.3° to 98.1°. If each chelating carboxylate groups is treated as one connecting point, the nickel center has a pseudotetrahedral geometry . Each Ni(II) atom is thus connected to four other Ni(II) centers, resulting in the formation of a diamondoid network. The Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni separations observed were in the range 10.65-13.13Å. The long spacers between the coordination sites result in large cavities with adamantanoid cages ( ). In order to minimize the big void cavities and to stabilize the framework naturally, the potential voids are effectively filled by mutual interpenetration of other two independent equivalent frameworks, generating a threefold network ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>[Co(3,5-pmb)(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Unlike compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has a 3D fourfold polyrotaxane structure. The network is constructed by binuclear molecules, in which each Co ion is tetrahedraly coordinated to two nitrogen atoms of different 3,5-pmb ligands (Co–N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.04<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and N–Co–N<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>102.06°) and two oxygen atoms of two different carboxylate groups in the monodentate mode from pmb and bdc ligands (Co–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.95<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and O–Co–O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>105.29°) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>). The whole network is constructed from four equivalent independent fragments. Each individual fragment consists of a ring and rod chains, in which the ring is constituted by two metal atoms bridged by two pmb ligands. These rings connect with each other via bdc (the rod) to form a chain, and then two adjacent chains are linked by the monodentate carboxylic group of the pmb ligand to form a 3D network. Interestingly, each chain is entangled with one chain from another equivalent independent fragment through the rod to form the polyrotaxane topology (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
[Co(3,5-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (2)

Unlike compound 1, compound 2 has a 3D fourfold polyrotaxane structure. The network is constructed by binuclear molecules, in which each Co ion is tetrahedraly coordinated to two nitrogen atoms of different 3,5-pmb ligands (Co-N=2.04Å and N-Co-N=102.06°) and two oxygen atoms of two different carboxylate groups in the monodentate mode from pmb and bdc ligands (Co-O=1.95Å and O-Co-O=105.29°) ( ). The whole network is constructed from four equivalent independent fragments. Each individual fragment consists of a ring and rod chains, in which the ring is constituted by two metal atoms bridged by two pmb ligands. These rings connect with each other via bdc (the rod) to form a chain, and then two adjacent chains are linked by the monodentate carboxylic group of the pmb ligand to form a 3D network. Interestingly, each chain is entangled with one chain from another equivalent independent fragment through the rod to form the polyrotaxane topology ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The most fascinating structural feature of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is that four equivalent networks with rotaxane entanglement are then interwoven with each other to give a 3D fourfold structure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para><ce:section-title>[Cd(3,5-pmb)(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">For complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that it has a unique 2D coordination network consisting of [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] units bridged by bdc and pmb ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig7"></ce:float-anchor>). Each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by one nitrogen atom of a pmb ligand and four oxygen atoms from the carboxylate group of pmb and bdc, in which the four carboxylate oxygen atoms comprise the equatorial plane and the N atom occupies the vertex of square-pyramidal structure to give a square-pyramidal coordinated geormetry. The average Cd–O bond length is 2.233<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the Cd–N bond length is 2.239<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Two adjacent Cd(II) atoms are bridged equivalently by four carboxylate groups of different pmb and bdc ligands, forming a paddle wheel secondary building unit (SBU). The Cd···Cd separation is 3.12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is significantly shorter than those in reported discrete dimeric cadmium–tetracarboxylate complexes (3.278–3.452<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) , but slightly longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii 3.04<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å , suggesting that there should be no Cd···Cd bond in the SBU. There exits a crystallographic inversion center between the two Cd cores in each dinuclear unit.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The most fascinating structural feature of 2 is that four equivalent networks with rotaxane entanglement are then interwoven with each other to give a 3D fourfold structure ( ).

[Cd(3,5-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (3)

For complex 3, the X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that it has a unique 2D coordination network consisting of [Cd2(CO2)4] units bridged by bdc and pmb ligands ( ). Each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by one nitrogen atom of a pmb ligand and four oxygen atoms from the carboxylate group of pmb and bdc, in which the four carboxylate oxygen atoms comprise the equatorial plane and the N atom occupies the vertex of square-pyramidal structure to give a square-pyramidal coordinated geormetry. The average Cd-O bond length is 2.233Å and the Cd-N bond length is 2.239Å. Two adjacent Cd(II) atoms are bridged equivalently by four carboxylate groups of different pmb and bdc ligands, forming a paddle wheel secondary building unit (SBU). The Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd separation is 3.12Å, which is significantly shorter than those in reported discrete dimeric cadmium-tetracarboxylate complexes (3.278-3.452Å) , but slightly longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii 3.04Å , suggesting that there should be no Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd bond in the SBU. There exits a crystallographic inversion center between the two Cd cores in each dinuclear unit.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Two pmb ligands conect with two SBU units like arms to form a four membered ring with a Cd···Cd separation in the intersecting ring of 12.13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å The rings are extended to form 1D fragments along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis, which are extended into a ladder-like 2D network via the bdc ligand (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig8"></ce:float-anchor>). The arms of each fragment intervene with ones of adjacent fragments without any interlocking (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Two pmb ligands conect with two SBU units like arms to form a four membered ring with a Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd separation in the intersecting ring of 12.13Å The rings are extended to form 1D fragments along the c-axis, which are extended into a ladder-like 2D network via the bdc ligand ( ). The arms of each fragment intervene with ones of adjacent fragments without any interlocking ( ).

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Properties</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>IR spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The IR spectrum of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups at 1585 and 1384<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. The separation (<ce:italic>Δ</ce:italic>) υ<ce:inf loc="post">asym</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>υ<ce:inf loc="post">sym</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) is 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which is consistent with the type of coordination of the carboxylate groups. The peaks of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> centered at 1617 and 1389<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> should be assigned to antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups, respectively. The separation (<ce:italic>Δ</ce:italic>) value is 227<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, indicating the existence of a monodentate coordination mode . In complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the characteristic bands of the carboxylate groups are shown at 1550 and 1390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the for the antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands, respectively, with a <ce:italic>Δ</ce:italic> value of ca. 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, indicating the presence of a bis-bidentate coordination mode .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Properties

IR spectroscopy

The IR spectrum of complex 1 shows typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups at 1585 and 1384cm-1, respectively. The separation (Δ) υasym(CO2)-υsym(CO2) is 200cm-1, which is consistent with the type of coordination of the carboxylate groups. The peaks of compound 2 centered at 1617 and 1389cm-1 should be assigned to antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups, respectively. The separation (Δ) value is 227cm-1, indicating the existence of a monodentate coordination mode . In complex 3, the characteristic bands of the carboxylate groups are shown at 1550 and 1390cm-1 for the for the antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands, respectively, with a Δ value of ca. 160cm-1, indicating the presence of a bis-bidentate coordination mode .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Luminescent properties</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The solid-state luminescence property of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was investigated at room temperature. Interestingly, the emission spectrum for complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> shows a main peak at 466<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm with a shoulder at about 410<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 373<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig10"></ce:float-anchor>). In order to understand the nature of this emission band, we analyzed the photoluminescent property of the pmb ligand and found that the strongest emission peak for pmb apears at 406<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 346<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, whereas the emission peak for H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc apears at 390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm . So the shoulder peak of the emission spectrum at 410<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is probably due to an intraligand energy transition, while the emission band at 466<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm may be assigned to a metal–ligand charge transfer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent properties

The solid-state luminescence property of complex 3 was investigated at room temperature. Interestingly, the emission spectrum for complex 3 shows a main peak at 466nm with a shoulder at about 410nm upon excitation at 373nm ( ). In order to understand the nature of this emission band, we analyzed the photoluminescent property of the pmb ligand and found that the strongest emission peak for pmb apears at 406nm upon excitation at 346nm, whereas the emission peak for H2bdc apears at 390nm upon excitation at 350nm . So the shoulder peak of the emission spectrum at 410nm of complex 3 is probably due to an intraligand energy transition, while the emission band at 466nm may be assigned to a metal-ligand charge transfer.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Three new Ni(II), Co(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers with different structural motifs based on mixed bdc and dipyridylbenzoates ligands (pmb) have been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a 3D threefold interpenetrated adamantanoid architecture, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has a 3D fourfold with rotaxane topology, and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a 2D network with paddle wheel dimeric cadmium tetracarboxylate building units. In summary, our research demonstrates that the dipyridylbenzoates ligand (pmb) could be a potential bridging ligand to construct novel supramolecular architectures with different structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three new Ni(II), Co(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers with different structural motifs based on mixed bdc and dipyridylbenzoates ligands (pmb) have been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. Complex 1 has a 3D threefold interpenetrated adamantanoid architecture, 2 has a 3D fourfold with rotaxane topology, and 3 is a 2D network with paddle wheel dimeric cadmium tetracarboxylate building units. In summary, our research demonstrates that the dipyridylbenzoates ligand (pmb) could be a potential bridging ligand to construct novel supramolecular architectures with different structures.

Syntheses of the ligands and the complexes

Synthesis of 3,5-pmb and 3,4-pmb

3,5-Dihydroxybenzoic acid (15.4g), ethanol (53ml) and sulfuric acid (4ml) were mixed and refluxed for 6-7h. The excess ethanol was removed under vacuum, and then the reaction mixture was extracted with ethylacetate. The extracted solution was washed once with water, and then with NaHCO3 aqueous solution. After drying with Na2SO4, the solvent was evaporated. To 20mmol (3.64g) of the product, 40mmol (6.5g) of 4-pycolyl chloride hydrochloride and 120mmol (4.8g) of NaOH and 10ml DMF were added. The mixture was heated at 70°C for 10h, and then the product was washed with ethanol and filtered. The solid product was transferred to a 100ml round bottom flask, 50ml of 5% NaOH solution was added and the resulting solution was refluxed at 70°C for 5h, then the mixture was transferred into a 400ml beaker. After adding 50ml of distilled and concentrated HCl drop by drop, a light brown precipitate was obtained at about pH 6, which was washed with ethanol and filtered. Yield: 72%. Anal. Calc. for C19H16N2O4 (336.11): C, 67.85; H, 4.79; N, 8.33%. Found: C, 67.91; H, 4.98; N, 8.26%. M.p. for the crude product is 128°C.

The synthetical method of 3,4-pmb was similar to the synthesis of 3,5-pmb, except that 3,4-dihydroxybenzoic acid was used instead of 3,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid. Yield: 60%. Anal. Calc. for C19H16N2O4 (336.11): C, 67.85; H, 4.79; N, 8.33. Found: C, 67.91; H, 4.98; N, 8.26%.

[Ni(3,4-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (1)

Compound 1 was prepared from a mixture of NiCl2 ⋅6H2O (0.3mmol, 0.066g), 3,4-pmb (0.2mmol, 0.073g), bdc (0.2mmol, 0.033g) and NaOH (0.6mmol, 0.024g) in 8ml distilled water. This mixture was heated in a sealed Teflon lined steel autoclave at 150°C for three days. After the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10°C/h, green crystals of 1 were obtained (yield: 58% based on Ni). Anal. Calc. for C23H15N2O10Ni (538.08): C, 51.34; H, 2.81; N, 5.21. Found: C, 50.69; H, 2.79; N, 5.20%.

[Co(3,5-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (2)

A mixture of Co(OAc)2 ⋅2H2O (0.3mmol, 0.075g), 3,5-pmb (0.2mmol, 0.073g), bdc (0.2mmol, 0.033g) and NaOH (0.6mmol,0.024g) was dissolved in 8ml distilled water. The mixture was heated in sealed Teflon lined steel autoclave at 150°C for three days. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 10°C/h, crystals of the product were obtained (yield: 52% based on Co). Anal. Calc. for C23H17N2O6Co (476.32): C, 58.00; H, 3.60; N, 5.88. Found: C, 57.96; H, 3.20; N, 5.79%.

[Cd(3,5-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (3)

The procedure was similar to the synthesis of complex 2 except that Cd(OAc)2 ⋅2H2O (0.3mmol, 0.08g) was used instead of Co(OAc)2 ⋅2H2O. Yield: 64% based on Cd. Anal. Calc. for C23H17N2O6Cd (529.79): C, 54.91; H, 3.41; N, 5.57. Found: C, 54.85; H, 3.32; N, 5.55%.

cln_elements.clean_text:
[Ni(3,4-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (1)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 has a 3D threefold interpenetrated adamantanoid structure. As is shown in  , each Ni(II) center adopts a distorted octahedral geometry, supplied by two nitrogen atoms from different 3,4-pmb ligands (the average Ni-N distance is 2.037Å and the N-Ni-N angle is 94.82°), and four oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of bdc and pmb in a chelating mode. The Ni-O bond distances are in the range 2.07-2.14Å, and the O-Ni-O bond angles range from 62.3° to 98.1°. If each chelating carboxylate groups is treated as one connecting point, the nickel center has a pseudotetrahedral geometry . Each Ni(II) atom is thus connected to four other Ni(II) centers, resulting in the formation of a diamondoid network. The Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni separations observed were in the range 10.65-13.13Å. The long spacers between the coordination sites result in large cavities with adamantanoid cages ( ). In order to minimize the big void cavities and to stabilize the framework naturally, the potential voids are effectively filled by mutual interpenetration of other two independent equivalent frameworks, generating a threefold network ( ).

The most fascinating structural feature of 2 is that four equivalent networks with rotaxane entanglement are then interwoven with each other to give a 3D fourfold structure ( ).

[Cd(3,5-pmb)(bdc)0.5] (3)

For complex 3, the X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that it has a unique 2D coordination network consisting of [Cd2(CO2)4] units bridged by bdc and pmb ligands ( ). Each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by one nitrogen atom of a pmb ligand and four oxygen atoms from the carboxylate group of pmb and bdc, in which the four carboxylate oxygen atoms comprise the equatorial plane and the N atom occupies the vertex of square-pyramidal structure to give a square-pyramidal coordinated geormetry. The average Cd-O bond length is 2.233Å and the Cd-N bond length is 2.239Å. Two adjacent Cd(II) atoms are bridged equivalently by four carboxylate groups of different pmb and bdc ligands, forming a paddle wheel secondary building unit (SBU). The Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd separation is 3.12Å, which is significantly shorter than those in reported discrete dimeric cadmium-tetracarboxylate complexes (3.278-3.452Å) , but slightly longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii 3.04Å , suggesting that there should be no Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd bond in the SBU. There exits a crystallographic inversion center between the two Cd cores in each dinuclear unit.

Properties

IR spectroscopy

The IR spectrum of complex 1 shows typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups at 1585 and 1384cm-1, respectively. The separation (Δ) υasym(CO2)-υsym(CO2) is 200cm-1, which is consistent with the type of coordination of the carboxylate groups. The peaks of compound 2 centered at 1617 and 1389cm-1 should be assigned to antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups, respectively. The separation (Δ) value is 227cm-1, indicating the existence of a monodentate coordination mode . In complex 3, the characteristic bands of the carboxylate groups are shown at 1550 and 1390cm-1 for the for the antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands, respectively, with a Δ value of ca. 160cm-1, indicating the presence of a bis-bidentate coordination mode .

Luminescent properties

The solid-state luminescence property of complex 3 was investigated at room temperature. Interestingly, the emission spectrum for complex 3 shows a main peak at 466nm with a shoulder at about 410nm upon excitation at 373nm ( ). In order to understand the nature of this emission band, we analyzed the photoluminescent property of the pmb ligand and found that the strongest emission peak for pmb apears at 406nm upon excitation at 346nm, whereas the emission peak for H2bdc apears at 390nm upon excitation at 350nm . So the shoulder peak of the emission spectrum at 410nm of complex 3 is probably due to an intraligand energy transition, while the emission band at 466nm may be assigned to a metal-ligand charge transfer.
